head.title: It Takes a Skeptic to Ignore Global Warming;The Need to Disprove

hedline.hl1: It Takes a Skeptic to Ignore Global Warming;The Need to Disprove

block.p: Your June 18 Science Times article on Richard S. Lindzen and his skepticism about predictions of global climate change gives a misleading impression of the nature of the scientific debate. Dr. Lindzen is far from alone in his quest to overthrow the accepted wisdom of his field.

Your June 18 Science Times article on Richard S. Lindzen and his skepticism about predictions of global climate change gives a misleading impression of the nature of the scientific debate. Dr. Lindzen is far from alone in his quest to overthrow the accepted wisdom of his field.

Modern science is built on the process of posing hypotheses and testing them against observations -- in essence, attempting to show they are incorrect. Nothing brings recognition more quickly than overthrowing the conventional wisdom of a field.

What is surprising about Dr. Lindzen is that, of the hundreds of researchers striving with careful, detailed studies to make breakthroughs in the study of the climate system, very few find evidence to support the idea that greenhouse warming is unlikely, harebrained or unimportant. The greenhouse concept may still have a fatal flaw, but it does not have a clear, simple flaw sufficient to convince the rest of the research community. JOSEPH A. BERRY CHRISTOPHER B. FIELD Stanford, Calif., June 18, 1996 The writers are, respectively, senior staff scientist and staff scientist, department of plant biology, Carnegie Institution of Washington.
